questions.question: A 35-year-old woman presents with B/L hilar lymphadenopathy without any significant lung parenchymal involvement. Her chest X-ray shows symmetric mediastinal and hilar lymphadenopathy in a "1-2-3" pattern. What is the most likely stage of sarcoidosis in this patient?
questions.explanation: Correct answer: B) Stage 1 Explanation: Stage 1 sarcoidosis is characterized by hilar/mediastinal lymphadenopathy without lung parenchymal changes . The “1-2-3” pattern refers to bilateral hilar and right paratracheal lymphadenopathy. Sarcoidosis Sarcoidosis is a multisystem inflammatory disorder characterized by the formation of noncaseating granulomas, with an unknown cause. Staging of Sarcoidosis Stage 0 No visible abnormalities Stage 1 Hilar/mediastinal lymphadenopathy without lung parenchymal changes (Option B) Stage 2 Hilar/mediastinal lymphadenopathy with lung disease (Option C) Stage 3 Diffuse lung disease without lymphadenopathy (Option D) Stage 4 End-stage fibrosis (Option A) Nodal Abnormalities : Found in up to 90% of patients, typically involving hilar and mediastinal lymph nodes. Common CXR findings include: Symmetric mediastinal and hilar lymphadenopathy. "1–2–3" pattern (Garland sign) : Right paratracheal, right hilar, and left hilar enlargement. "1–2–3–4" pattern: Includes enlarged aortopulmonary lymph nodes. The egg shell calcification is seen late in the disease Scintigraphy: The Gallium-67 scan shows: Panda sign: It indicates bilateral involvement of the parotid and lacrimal glands, along with normal uptake in the nasopharyngeal mucosa. Lambda sign: This condition usually affects bilateral hilar and right paratracheal lymph nodes, which can form a shape similar to the Greek letter lambda ( λ ). Classical HRCT Findings: Well-defined, smooth or irregular nodules (2-4 mm) in a perilymphatic distribution, primarily in the upper lobes. Nodules may cluster or coalesce into larger formations.A large pulmonary nodule made up of several smaller nodules and encircled by numerous tiny satellite nodules is referred to as the "galaxy sign.” Bilateral hilar and mediastinal lymph node enlargement. Possible upper lobe fibrosis.

questions.question: A 65-year-old male presents with fever, cough, and pleuritic chest pain. X-ray chest is performed, revealing an air bronchogram. Which of the following conditions is characterized by the absence of air bronchograms?
questions.explanation: Correct answer: A) Pleural effusion Explanation: Pleural effusion is least likely to demonstrate air bronchograms, as it involves fluid in the pleural space and does not typically affect the visibility of air-filled bronchi in the lung parenchyma. Air bronchogram: Pattern of air-filled (low-attenuation) bronchi on a background of opaque (high-attenuation) airless lung. Significance: Indicates patency of proximal airways. Suggests evacuation of alveolar air due to: Absorption (atelectasis). Replacement (e.g., pneumonia). Or a combination of these processes. Persistence of gas in the bronchi indicates patency of proximal airways. Seen in pulmonary parenchymal lesions and absent in extrapulmonary processes such as pleural effusion. questions.question: A 45-year-old male presents with a chronic cough and mild chest discomfort. A chest X-ray reveals a mediastinal mass with well-defined margins and a paravertebral location, suggestive of a lesion arising from neural tissue. To confirm the diagnosis and further evaluate the mass, the physician orders additional imaging. What is the most appropriate imaging modality to confirm the diagnosis?

options.C: CT scan of the chest with contrast

questions.explanation: Correct answer: A) MRI of the chest Explanation: MRI is the preferred imaging modality for posterior mediastinal masses, particularly those suspected to arise from neural structures. It provides excellent soft tissue contrast and allows detailed visualization of the mass and its relationship with surrounding tissues, making it ideal for evaluating neurogenic tumors. Felson classification of the mediastinum: Felson classification divides the mediastinum into three anatomical compartments to assist in the localization and diagnosis of mediastinal masses. These compartments are based on lateral chest radiographs. Compartment Boundaries Common Masses/Abnormalities Anterior (Prevascular) Posterior sternum to anterior heart and great vessels Thymic masses: Thymoma, thymic hyperplasia, thymic carcinoma Germ cell tumors: Teratoma Thyroid masses: Ectopic thyroid, substernal goiter Lymphoma: Hodgkin's, non-Hodgkin's Middle (Visceral) Between anterior and posterior compartments Contains heart, great vessels, trachea, esophagus, lymph nodes Bronchogenic cysts Pericardial cysts Lymphadenopathy (metastasis, lymphoma, sarcoidosis) Aortic aneurysms, vascular abnormalities Posterior (Paravertebral) Posterior heart and great vessels to anterior vertebrae Neurogenic tumors: Schwannomas, neurofibromas, ganglioneuromas Esophageal lesions: Tumors, diverticula Spinal abnormalities : Vertebral infections, hernias, masses

questions.question: A 55-year-old male presents with drooping of the right eyelid, a constricted right pupil, and lack of sweating on the right side of his face. He also reports weakness, pain, and numbness in his right arm. Chest x-ray reports an apical lung mass on the right side. What is the imaging modality of choice to identify the underlying cause of his symptoms?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) MRI Explanation: The clinical features of Horner's syndrome (ptosis, miosis, anhidrosis) combined with brachial plexopathy (arm weakness, pain, and numbness) strongly suggest a Pancoast tumor, which is a lung apex tumor often affecting the sympathetic chain and brachial plexus. MRI is the preferred imaging modality as it provides detailed visualization of soft tissues, including the tumor’s invasion into surrounding structures like the brachial plexus. CT Scan (Computed Tomography): Modality of choice for the detailed evaluation of lung tumors. PET-CT (Positron Emission Tomography-CT): Modality of choice for staging and assessing metastatic spread , as malignant cells show increased glucose metabolism. Combines metabolic imaging (via PET) with anatomic detail (via CT). MRI (Magnetic Resonance Imaging): Not routinely used for lung tumors, but valuable in specific cases. Superior sulcus tumors (Pancoast tumors): Investigation of choice in pancoast tumors to assess brachial plexus involvement or spinal cord invasion. Chest X-ray (Option A): Incorrect — suggests the presence of mass but does not define nerve or soft tissue invasion. CT Scan (Option C): Incorrect — good for bony detail but not optimal for brachial plexus or sympathetic chain evaluation. PET Scan (Option D): Incorrect — useful for staging , not for assessing local neurological invasion .

questions.question: A 60-year-old man with a history of working as a shipyard worker presents with progressive dyspnea, a persistent dry cough, and chest tightness. He also reports recent weight loss and has experienced crackles upon auscultation. A CT scan of the chest reveals a distinct structure. What could be the underlying mechanism responsible for the observed sign on the CT image?

options.A: Round atelectasis causing a distinct pattern of lung collapse.
options.B: Calcified pleural plaques resulting in alterations in the pleural surface.
options.C: A large nodule surrounded by small nodules indicating a significant inflammatory process.
options.D: Interstitial fibrosis leading to a reticular pattern affecting lung architecture.

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Round atelectasis causing a distinct pattern of lung collapse. Explanation: Round atelectasis occurs when lung tissue collapses, resulting in the characteristic comet tail sign on CT due to the distinct radiographic appearance. Asbestosis Asbestosis is a chronic lung disease caused by the inhalation of asbestos fibers, primarily affecting workers in occupations such as plumbing, shipbuilding, and construction. It is classified as an occupational lung disease, characterized by progressive pulmonary fibrosis and pleural abnormalities. It affects lower lobes predominantly. Radiological Signs: Sign/Condition Features Pleural Plaques Holly Leaf Sign: Calcified pleural plaques, exhibiting irregular, thickened nodular edges that resemble the shape of a holly leaf. Mesothelioma Radiological Feature: Irregular thickening of the pleura, often involving the mediastinal pleura, leading to fibrothorax/ frozen. Comet Tail Sign (Crow's Feet Sign) Mechanism: Localized atelectasis with adjacent blood vessels and bronchi drawn towards the collapsed area. Appearance: Rounded

questions.question: A 65-year-old male presents with progressive dyspnea, a dry cough, and weight loss over the past six months. On examination, clubbing of the fingers is noted. A chest CT scan reveals a predominantly subpleural reticular pattern with areas of honeycombing predominantly affecting the lower lobes. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct answer: B) Usual Interstitial Pneumonia (UIP) Explanation: The clinical presentation includes progressive dyspnea, a dry cough, and clubbing, which are common in interstitial lung diseases , and the Predominantly subpleural reticular pattern with honeycombing , especially in the lower lobes confirm UIP. Usual Interstitial Pneumonia (UIP) Non-Specific Interstitial Pneumonia (NSIP) (Option A) It presents as a mainly subpleural bibasal reticular pattern with areas of honeycomb (subpleural cystic airspaces with discrete, thickened walls that are stacked or lined up in a row) destruction. As the disease advances, it tends to spread along the lung periphery , affecting the anterior parts of the upper lobes , referred to as the 'propeller blade distribution.' There are signs of traction bronchiectasis and bronchiolectasis. Ground-glass opacities are not predominant. Bilateral ground-glass opacities accompanied by fine reticular patterns . Primarily peripheral in distribution , but may also appear patchy or band-like. Minimal or absent honeycomb pattern. Presence of traction bronchiectasis and bronchiolectasis. Subpleural sparing is seen. Cryptogenic organizing pneumonia (Option C) Opacities may appear consolidative, ground-glass, nodular, or mass-like. Typical distribution is subpleural or peribronchovascular. A common appearance is the perilobular pattern, which features linear or band-like opacities arranged in an arcade or polygonal shape . The “atoll” or “reversed halo sign ” is characterized by central ground-glass opacity with a surrounding consolidative edge. Sarcoidosis generally features bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy with egg shell calcification of hilar lymph nodes and ground-glass opacities. (Option D)

questions.question: The most common HRCT finding in a patient with COVID-19 is:
questions.explanation: Correct answer: B) Ground-glass opacities Explanation: The most common HRCT finding in COVID-19 is ground-glass opacities. CT Findings of COVID-19 : Common Findings: Ground-glass opacities (GGO) (M/c), consolidation , and reticulations . Characteristic Patterns : Bilateral peripheral and lower lobe predominance; features may resemble organizing pneumonia. A reversed halo sign, halo sign , reticulations, and nodules are uncommon and usually appear later . Other atypical findings can include cavitation, isolated lobar or segmental consolidation, lymphadenopathy, pneumothorax, pneumomediastinum, and pleural effusions. Reference: David Sutton Textbook of Radiology & Imaging, 8th Edition, Volume 1, Page 994, 996

questions.question: Popcorn calcification in lung is seen in:
questions.explanation: Correct answer: D) Pulmonary hamartoma Explanation: Pulmonary Hamartoma: Hamartomas are the most common benign lung tumors, Generally asymptomatic and often discovered incidentally Radiographic Features: Typically present as a solitary peripheral pulmonary nodule or mass. Size usually ranges from 1 to 4 cm. Well-circumscribed, round or oval shape with smooth or lobulated margins. Internal calcifications, often with a "popcorn" appearance CT scans effectively reveal internal fat , which is pathognomonic for hamartomas. Hamartomas may be multiple, grow slowly, and do not cavitate or invade adjacent structures. Reference: Grainger & Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology 7th Edition, Page 117, 118 David Sutton Textbook of Radiology & Imaging 8th Edition, Volume 1, Page 265,1056 https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK542329/ https://link.springer.com/chapter/10.1007/978-3-031-24494-0_33

questions.question: A 28-year-old shepherd presents with chronic cough and occasional hemoptysis. A chest X-ray is shown below. Which of the following radiological signs is most likely represented in this image?
questions.explanation: Correct answer: C) Water Lily sign Explanation: The clinical feature of chronic cough with occasional hemoptysis in a patient with livestock exposure, along with the characteristic Water Lily sign on chest x-ray, points towards the diagnosis of a ruptured pulmonary hydatid cyst. Radiographic Findings of Hydatid Cyst : Uncomplicated cysts appear as thin-walled, round or oval masses with low-attenuation contents and a thin enhancing wall, up to 10 cm in size. Signs of Impending Rupture : Meniscus Sign : Air lucency between the pericyst and laminated membranes when cyst communicates with bronchioles. Curvilinear membrane outlined by air both inside the endocyst and a crescent of air between the endocyst and pericyst. (Option B & D) Water Lily Sign : Also known as the camalote sign. questions.explanation: consolidation with satellite nodules in the right middle and lower zone' is an indicator of active pulmonary tuberculosis. Primary Tuberculosis: Pathology: Characterized by macrophage infiltration, monocytes, and inflammatory fluid in peripheral pneumonia. Spread to regional nodes and bodies occurs within 2 to 6 weeks. Chest X-ray: Homogeneous lobar consolidation (any lobe), often indistinguishable from other bacterial pneumonia. Lymphadenopathy is the most common manifestation. Ghon lesion or focus: Well-defined rounded or irregular (linear) opacity with or without calcification. Ranke complex: Combination of Ghon lesion and ipsilateral lymph node calcification. Reactivation and Reinfection of Tuberculosis Most cases result from reactivation of quiescent lesions, occasionally from new infections. Pathologically, the host's immune response leads to increased inflammatory response and caseous necrosis. Imaging: Absence of lymphadenopathy Frequent cavitation (indicates active disease) Predilection for upper lobes. Rasmussen aneurysm: Inflammatory pseudo-aneurysmal dilatation of a branch of pulmonary artery adjacent to a tuberculous cavity. Endobronchial spread: May cause "tree-in-bud" appearance on imaging. Healing leads to scar formation, volume loss, and pleural thickening. Tuberculoma: Localized parenchymal disease, usually calcifies and often remains stable for years, sometimes with satellite nodules. questions.question: Match the following: Disease Radiologic Finding A) Klebsiella Pneumonia 1) Reticular Shadows B) Aspergilloma 2) Air Bronchogram C) Staphylococcal Pneumonia 3) Bulging Fissure Sign D) Acute Epiglottitis 4) Air-Crescent Sign E) Pneumocystis carinii Pneumonia 5) Thumb Sign
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) A3, B4, C2, D5, E1 Explanation: Klebsiella Pneumonia: Bulging fissure sign : Seen when lobar consolidation causes expansion of the affected lung, displacing adjacent fissures. Aspergilloma: Air-crescent sign: Typically indicates the presence of a fungal ball within a cavity. Staphylococcal Pneumonia: Air Bronchogram: Occurs when endobronchial air is visible against a background of increased lung opacity. Expulsion of gas from the parenchyma can be due to atelectasis and/ replacement by fluid, inflammatory cells, blood, tumor, or interstitial thickening. Persistence of gas in the bronchi implies patency of proximal airways. Acute Epiglottitis: Thumb sign: Refers to the appearance of an edematous and enlarged epiglottis seen on a lateral soft-tissue radiograph of the neck. Pneumocystis carinii Pneumonia: Reticular shadows/opacities: Caused by a decrease in the gas to soft tissue ratio due to a pathological process centered in or around the pulmonary interstitium. This includes thickening of interstitial compartments by blood, fluid, tumor, cells, fibrous tissue, or a combination of these factors.

questions.question: A 45-year-old male presents with a cough, dyspnea, and fever. A chest radiograph shows loss of the right heart border. Which lung area is most likely affected?
questions.explanation: Correct answer: B) Right middle lobe Explanation: The loss of the right heart border indicates pathology in the right middle lobe based on Silhouette sign. Silhouette Sign: Absence of the depiction of an anatomic soft-tissue border. Produced by an intrathoracic abnormality that touches the borders of the heart or aorta and obliterates those borders on the frontal chest radiograph. The sign actually refers to the absence of a silhouette. Silhouette sign helps localize airspace opacities, atelectasis, or masses in the lung. Loss of normal silhouettes on frontal chest radiographs indicates the site of pathology: Right paratracheal stripe : Right upper lobe (Option A) Right heart border : Right middle lobe or medial right lower lobe (Option B) Right hemidiaphragm : Right lower lobe (Option C) Aortic knuckle : Left upper lobe (Option D) Left heart border : Lingular segments of the left upper lobe Left hemidiaphragm or descending aorta : Left lower lobe Reference: 1. https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK370/#:~ 2. https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK470197/# 3. https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/medgen/1778950 4. https://www.sciencedirect.com/topics/medicine-and-dentistry/silhouette-sign#

questions.question: A medical student is learning to identify anterior and posterior ribs on a PA chest X-ray. Identify the labeled rib shown below:
questions.explanation: Correct answer: D) 6th Posterior rib Explanation: The labelled rib is the 6 th posterior rib. Rib Counting in chest X-ray: Posterior ribs are more visible and appear horizontal. Anterior ribs are less visible and angle downwards. Identify the first rib, which may be difficult due to crowding at the apex. It’s easier to locate the anterior part of the first rib first. Follow this backward to find the posterior part of the first rib. Count the posterior ribs downward from the first rib.

questions.question: A 35-year-old woman presents with a chronic productive cough and recurrent episodes of foul-smelling sputum and hemoptysis. A high-resolution CT (HRCT) of the chest is shown below. Which of the following radiological signs is most characteristic of the condition seen in this image?
questions.explanation: Correct answer: C) Tram track sign Explanation: The clinical feature of chronic productive cough with recurrent foul-smelling sputum and hemoptysis suggests chronic suppurative lung disease. This, along with the characteristic "tram track sign" seen on high-resolution CT, points towards a diagnosis of bronchiectasis . Radiographic Findings of Bronchiectasis: Tramline Sign/Tram track sign (Option C): Thickened bronchial walls seen as single thick lines or parallel line opacities. Cystic bronchiectasis: Multiple thin-walled ring shadows with air-fluid levels. Computed Tomographic (CT) Findings: Major sign: Bronchial dilation, with or without bronchial wall thickening. Lack of tapering of bronchial lumina. Signet ring sign: Bronchial diameter greater than the adjacent pulmonary artery. Glove-finger/V/Y-shaped densities: Represent mucus-filled dilated bronchi. Tree-in-bud sign (Option A): More commonly seen with endobronchial spread of tuberculosis. Also seen in bronchiolitis as small nodular and branching opacities. Ground-glass opacities (Option B) are hazy areas of increased lung opacity with preserved bronchial and vascular markings, typically seen in interstitial lung diseases, viral infections, or pulmonary edema, not in airway dilation. questions.question: A 30-year-old female presents with sudden-onset chest pain and difficulty breathing after a recent blunt trauma to the chest. Chest CT is taken and is shown below. Which of the following radiological findings is not typically seen in this case?
questions.explanation: Correct answer: A) Barcode sign Explanation: Chest CT reveals signs of pneumomediastinum with the presence of air surrounding the heart and in the subcutaneous tissues of the neck. Barcode or stratosphere sign is typically found in patients with pneumothorax, not pneumomediastinum. Pneumomediastinum: Presence of free air around mediastinal structures. Common Causes: Blunt or penetrating trauma. Esophageal perforation. Hamman's crunch sign: Unusual, adventitious sound heard on auscultation of the chest. Radiographic Signs: Ring around the artery sign: Air around the pulmonary artery (usually the right) outlining the artery. Sail sign: Elevation of the thymus caused by air. Continuous diaphragm sign : Air trapped posterior to the pericardium, appearing as a continuous air collection on an AP projection. (Option C) Tubular artery sign : Air outlines the medial side of major aortic branches, with aerated lung outlining the lateral side. (Option A) Double bronchial wall sign : Air adjacent to the bronchus highlights the bronchial wall. (Option D) Naclerio V-sign: V-shaped air lucency in the left lower mediastinal area. Ginkgo leaf sign: Subcutaneous emphysema over anterior chest wall. Subcutaneous emphysema, a different way to diagnose. questions.question: A 68-year-old male patient presents with cough, fever, and pleuritic chest pain. A contrast CT is taken and shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis for this patient?
questions.explanation: Correct answer: B) Empyema Explanation: Clinical symptoms, including cough, fever, and pleuritic chest pain, along with the CT finding of a low-attenuating pleural fluid collection between the enhancing visceral (white arrow) and parietal pleura (black arrow), i.e., Split-pleura sign , confirms the diagnosis of Empyema. Lung Abscess (Option D) typically appears as a localized, well-defined mass with an air-fluid level within the lung parenchyma rather than in the pleural space.

questions.question: A 75-year-old male patient with a history of congestive heart failure presents with worsening shortness of breath and pleuritic chest pain. A chest X-ray PA view is taken, which is shown below. Which of the following statements about the finding on the chest X-ray is most accurate?

options.A: It is most commonly with effusion occupying the oblique fissure.
options.B: It may be mistaken for a lung mass due to its appearance.
options.C: It will typically require surgical intervention to resolve.
options.D: It is always associated with exudative pleural effusion.

questions.explanation: Correct answer: B) It may be mistaken for a lung mass due to its appearance. Explanation: Chest X-ray reveals a well-defined homogeneous mass occupying the transverse fissure in the right middle lung field in a patient with heart failure, suggesting a diagnosis of a phantom tumor , which may be mistaken for a lung mass due to its mass-like radiologic appearance. Phantom Tumor/ Vanishing Tumor: A phantom tumor is a well-demarcated opacity resulting from pleural effusion. It is commonly associated with congestive heart failure. The effusion is typically transudative in nature. (Option D) The most commonly described appearance is a well-defined homogeneous mass, occupying the transverse fissure or sometimes the oblique interlobar fissures. (Option A) It may be mistaken for a lung mass or consolidation because of its radiologic appearance as a mass-like configuration in the lung. (Option B) It vanishes following mobilization of the fluid and effective diuresis. (Option C) Mostly seen in the geriatric population who have a higher incidence of congestive heart failure. Pathophysiology: In congestive heart failure, increased hydrostatic pressure on the right side of the lung interferes with venous and lymphatic drainage. This leads to a predominance of effusion on the right side. Pleuritis can cause obliteration of the pleural space, preventing the spread of fluid. Treatment: Diuretics

questions.question: A 65-year-old male with a history of COPD presents with a 2-week history of increasing shortness of breath and a persistent cough. On examination, decreased breath sounds are noted on the left, and a chest X-ray is taken, which is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct answer: C) Pleural effusion Explanation: Clinical features like breathlessness, cough, and decreased breath sound, along with X-ray findings of large pleural opacity and blunted costophrenic angle, indicate a diagnosis of Pleural effusion. Pleural Effusion: Pleural effusion is the accumulation of fluid in the pleural space. Effusion Progression: Blunting of costophrenic angles starts at 200-500 mL. Classic signs include opacification of the lower chest with a concave superior margin. Massive Effusions: 1000 mL reaches the fourth anterior rib; cause dense opacification of the hemithorax with contralateral mediastinal shift. Diaphragmatic inversion may occur. Lateral decubitus X-rays: Increase sensitivity for small effusions as the pleural fluid moves with gravity and the lung effectively floats on the effusion. Subpulmonary Effusions: Appear as a "high hemidiaphragm" on x-rays, with an unusual contour that peaks laterally than usual. Ultrasound or CT confirms the diagnosis. In an upright PA view, the meniscus sign indicates the presence of a significant amount of pleural fluid, typically exceeding 200 mL and blunting the costophrenic angle. Lung abscess (Option A) typically presents with a cavitary lesion on imaging, often accompanied by a gas-fluid level, rather than a pleural opacity with a blunted costophrenic angle indicative of fluid accumulation seen in pleural effusion. questions.question: A patient with a large tension pneumothorax after experiencing a fall is being examined with ultrasound. Which of the following findings will be present in this patient?
questions.explanation: signs are absent in this case of pneumothorax. Ultrasound findings in pneumothorax Pleural stripe (Option C) The echogenic line known as the 'pleural stripe' reflects most of the acoustic energy at the air-pleural interface and is the normal pleura . Artefacts Vertical echogenic bands called 'comet tails' are absent in pneumothorax . ' A lines' are horizontal reverberation artefacts caused by reflection from the pleura in the presence of pneumothorax. Lung sliding (Option A) It is a normal finding seen due to the shimmering of the pleural stripe at the pleural surface. This sign disappears in pneumothorax . Lung point sign Indicates the border between sliding lung and pneumothorax which helps assess size. Barcode/ stratosphere sign In cases where lung sliding is absent , M-mode images show uniform horizontal straight lines known as the stratosphere sign or barcode sign. This is seen in pneumothorax. Normal lung shows Sea-shore sign (Option B).

questions.question: A patient is brought to the emergency after a fall from a tree. He developed shortness of breath and chest pain, is tachypneic, and has distended neck veins on examination. His chest X-ray shows as follows: Which of the following is the correct finding here?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Collapsed lung The above clinical symptoms and the chest X-ray lead to the diagnosis of a right pneumothorax, which causes the lung to collapse and squished towards the hilum, ipsilateral depression of the hemidiaphragm, and contralateral deviation of the mediastinum. Pathophysiology: The pressure gradient in the thorax changes with pneumothorax. Normally, the pleural space is negative compared to atmospheric pressure. If air enters the pleural space through communication with the alveoli, it alters the pressure gradient, leading to lung collapse. Radiographic appearance of pneumothorax: Pneumothorax appears as a radiolucent area (black). Pneumothorax pushes the adjacent lung towards the hilum. A sharp radiopaque line separates the pneumothorax from the lung parenchyma. A closed pneumothorax is easily detectable in an expiratory X-ray, as there is a decrease in lung volume. However, the volume of the pneumothorax is not affected

questions.question: A patient presents to the clinic with the following anomalies of chest and hands. He has a history of having these anomalies since childhood but has no other symptoms. His chest X-ray shows a left hyperlucent lobe. Which other condition can show a similar chest X-ray picture?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Bullous emphysema The clinical scenario here points to the diagnosis of Poland syndrome, in which the chest radiograph shows a hyperlucent or blackout hemithorax of the affected side (left here), and this black-out lung finding is also found in other conditions like bullous emphysema. questions.question: A 55-year-old male presents with significant facial swelling, prominent neck veins, and difficulty breathing. These findings suggest an obstruction in the venous return from the head, neck, and upper limbs. A CT scan is conducted to assess the cause of these symptoms. In the diagram provided below, which of the following structures is most likely obstructed, leading to the clinical presentation observed in this patient?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) B Significant facial swelling, prominent neck veins, and difficulty breathing are characteristic of superior vena cava (SVC) syndrome. This condition arises due to obstruction of the SVC, impairing venous return from the head, neck, and upper limbs. The SVC is a major vein that collects blood from the upper body and returns it to the heart. When obstructed, venous pressure increases in the areas it drains, leading to facial and neck swelling (often with distended neck veins), dyspnea, and sometimes cyanosis. In the provided CT scan, structure B represents the SVC. Its obstruction results in the clinical manifestations of SVC syndrome.

questions.question: In a lateral chest X-ray, which area should you focus on to identify pathology in the hilar region?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) B In a lateral chest X-ray, the hilar region is typically located posteriorly and laterally within the mediastinum. Focusing on area B allows for optimal visualization of structures such as the pulmonary arteries, veins, and lymph nodes, which are critical in identifying potential pathologies like tumors, infections, or vascular changes. Area B is best suited for assessing any abnormalities that may indicate underlying disease in the hilar region. Normal anatomy, Chest radiograph (PA View and Lateral View) Fissures of the Lung and Hemidiaphragm in Chest Radiography Lung Fissures in Chest Radiography Right Lung Left Lung Three lobes: Upper, Middle, Lower Two lobes: Upper, Lower Fissures: Horizontal fissure: Separates the upper and middle lobes. Oblique fissure: Separates the middle from the lower lobe, and also divides the upper from the lower lobe. Fissures: Oblique (major) fissure: Separates the upper from the lower lobe. Clinical Relevance: Right Middle Lobe (RML) Collapse: Seen as a wedge-shaped opacity overlying the heart on lateral X-ray. Lobar Pneumonia: Fissures localize consolidation (e.g., obscured right heart border in RML pneumonia). Pleural Effusion: Blunts fissures due to fluid accumulation. Elevated Hemidiaphragm Flat Hemidiaphragm One side of the diaphragm appears higher than normal. The normally dome-shaped diaphragm appears flattened and lower in position. Causes: Subphrenic Abscess: Pus beneath diaphragm. Hepatomegaly/Splenomegaly: Enlarged organs push the diaphragm upward. Diaphragmatic Palsy : Paralysis due to phrenic nerve injury. Lung Collapse/Fibrosis : Loss of lung volume elevates the diaphragm. Atelectasis: Collapsed lung leads to diaphragm elevation. Causes: COPD: Hyperinflated lungs cause a flat diaphragm and tubular heart appearance. Tension Pneumothorax: Air pushes the diaphragm downward. Emphysema: Destruction of lung tissue results in diaphragm flattening.

questions.question: A 25-year-old male involved in a road traffic accident was stabilized in the field with needle decompression for severe shortness of breath, decreased breath sounds, and hyper-resonance on the right side of the chest. Upon arrival at the emergency department, he is hemodynamically stable. Which chest X-ray view is most appropriate to confirm the underlying condition?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Expiration Chest X-ray In expiration, the lung becomes white due to air exhaled out while pneumothorax remains black. So, white lung gives a good contrast to black pneumothorax in expiration. Chest X-ray: Inspiration vs. Expiration Chest X-ray in Inspiration: Chest X-rays are typically performed during the inspiration phase, which maximizes lung volume and provides a clearer view of the lung fields. During this phase, the lungs fill with air, and the air appears black on the X-ray due to its low density compared to surrounding tissues. Chest X-ray in Expiration: Expiratory chest X-rays are utilized for assessing small pneumothoraces and suspected inhaled foreign bodies, while inspiratory chest X-rays are performed in all other cases. Appearance During Expiration: When a foreign body obstructs the airway, air may become trapped in the lungs, preventing full exhalation. Consequently, during an expiratory X-ray, the obstructed lung appears black (due to retained air), indicating an obstruction on that particular side. A persistent black appearance in the affected lung can confirm an obstruction. Comparison of Normal Lung and Pneumothorax: Pneumothorax (inspiratory and expiratory x-rays). Inspiration Chest X-ray (Option A): Commonly used for general chest imaging but can miss small pneumothoraces since the lungs are fully expanded, hiding air in the pleural space. Lateral Decubitus Chest X-ray (Option C): Most sensitive chest x-ray view for pleural effusion. Oblique Chest X-ray (Option D): This view can be helpful for evaluating certain thoracic structures but is not typically used to assess pneumothorax.
